awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Embracing Complexity: A Fractal Calculus Approach to the Modeling and Optimization of Medical Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This cross-disciplinary research proposes a patient-specific cost-saving approach to the design and optimization of healthcare cyber-physical systems (HCPS). The HCPS computes the patient's physiological state based on sensors, communicates this information via a network from home to hospital for quantifying risk indices, signals the need for critical medical intervention in real time, and controls vital health signals (e.g., cardiac rhythm, blood glucose). The research proposed under the HCPS paradigm will treat the human body as a complex system. It will entail the development of mathematical models that capture the time-dependence and fractal behavior of physiological processes and the design of quality-of-life (QoL) control strategies for medical devices. The research will advance the understanding of the correlations between physiological processes, drug treatment, stress level and lifestyle. 

To date, the complex interdependence, variability and individual characteristics of physiological processes have not been taken into account in the design of medical devices and artificial organs. The existing mathematical approaches rely on reductionist and Markovian assumptions. This research project will rethink the theoretical foundations for the design of healthcare cyber-physical systems by capturing the interdependencies and fractal characteristics of physiological processes within a highly dynamic network. To establish the theoretical foundations of HCPS, a three-step approach will be followed: (i) construct a multi-scale non-equilibrium statistical physics inspired framework for patient modeling that captures the time dependence, non-Gaussian behavior, interdependencies and multi-fractal behavior of physiological processes; (ii) develop adaptive patient-specific and physiology-aware (multi-fractal) close-loop control algorithms for dynamic complex networks; (iii) design algorithms and methodologies for the HCPS networked components that account for biological and technological constraints. This research will significantly contribute to early chronic disease detection and treatment. Models and implementable algorithms, which can both predict physiological dynamics and assess the risk of acute and chronic diseases, will be valuable instruments for patient-centered healthcare. This in-depth mathematical analysis of physiological complexity facilitates a transformative multimodal and multi-scale approach to CPS design with healthcare applications.

The project not only addresses the current scientific and technological gap in CPS, but can also foster new research directions in related fields such as the study of interdependent networks with implications for understanding homeostasis and diseases and the study and control of complex systems. The cyber-physical systems designed under this newly proposed paradigm will have vital social and economic implications, including the improvement of QoL and the reduction of lost productivity rates due to chronic diseases. The project will offer interdisciplinary training for graduate, undergraduate and K-12 students. The PI will integrate the research results within his courses at University of Southern California and make them widely available through the project website. Moreover, the PI will enhance civic engagement by involving college and K-12 students in community outreach activities that will raise awareness of the important role of health monitoring.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The intricate interplay among genomic, proteomic, metabolic and physiological processes not only sustains human life but also encompasses the complex dynamics and multi-scale interactions between chemical, electrical, and mechanical components of the human body which serve as a basis for medical diagnosis. Rigorous mathematical analysis shows that many such processes are time dependent and possess multi-fractal characteristics. However, current diagnosis methods and medical devices (e.g., pacemakers, artificial pancreas, anesthesia systems, and brain-machine-body interfaces) do not account for these mathematical characteristics, thus, perpetuating an incomplete understanding of their complex dynamics and possibly leading to a lower quality-of-life (QoL). If these features were considered, many diseases (e.g., diabetes, heart disease) could be prevented or their onset could be delayed or more efficiently diagnosed and treated by using healthcare cyber-physical systems (HCPS). The HCPS can compute the patient?s physiological state based on sensors, communicate this information via a network from home to hospital for quantifying risk indices, signal the need for critical medical intervention in real time, and control vital health signals (e.g., cardiac rhythm, glucose). To enable the HCPS paradigm, it is pivotal to develop a science of cyber-physical systems (CPS). Instead of relying on reductive approaches to HCPS, this project constructed a complex systems approach that has considered the fractal behavior and interdependence of physiological processes.

To enable a science of healthcare CPSs, this project made the following contributions:

(1) The project constructed mathematical models that capture the interdependencies, non-stationarity and fractal behavior of physiological processes. The model structure and parameters reflect the intrinsic individual?s characteristics. For instance, we pioneer a mathematical modeling paradigm for constructing compact yet accurate models of complex systems dynamics that learns from noisy unstructured data streams the causal effects and influences among cyber and physical processes by analyzing the statistics of the magnitude increments and the inter-event times of stochastic processes. We provided the first general causal inference framework for reconstructing complex dynamic networks from partial observations subjected to unknown adversarial interventions.

(2) The project developed adaptive patient-specific and physiology-aware close-loop control strategies (e.g., multi-fractal control algorithms for dynamic complex networks) while accounting for the physiological interdependencies and interactions among control variables. For instance, we pioneer the multifractal weighted network generating measure formalism providing new, efficient and robust control strategies for large scale partially known complex dynamic networks subjected to unknown unknowns (unknown perturbations, stimuli, attacks). Moreover, we developed the first control methods for optimal driven node selection for complex dynamical networks with long-term memory.

(3) The project provided a comprehensive design methodology for the development of HCPS components. More precisely, it developed a time-varying CPS model, which accounted for the time dependence of computation and communication, and proposed algorithms for optimal parallelization and resource allocation in heterogeneous systems. With increasing demand for distributed intelligent CPSs performing big data analytics on the field and in real-time, we set forth a pioneering design methodology that automatically transforms, extracts and mines high level programs into essential universal intermediate representation graphs, identifies the optimal degree of parallelization, determines the optimal number of heterogeneous processing elements, size and type of memory as well as on-chip and off-chip interconnect, and efficiently maps and schedules the optimal parallelized task graphs to heterogeneous resources in real time.

This research project rethinks the theoretical foundations for the design of HCPSs by capturing the interdependencies and fractal characteristics of physiological processes within a highly dynamic network. The products from this project can significantly contribute to early chronic disease detection and treatment. Models and implementable algorithms, which can predict physiological dynamics and assess the risk of acute and chronic diseases, can be valuable instruments for patient-centered healthcare. This in-depth mathematical analysis of physiological complexity facilitates a transformative multimodal and multi-scale approach to CPS design.

The potential societal impacts of this research include mathematical models, algorithms and systems to enable early detection of disease signatures, prevention of catastrophic events, and treatment while minimizing costs related to hospitalization or side-effects. The project addressed the current scientific and technological gaps in CPS field and fosters new research directions in related fields such as the study of interdependent networks with implications for understanding homeostasis and diseases and the study and control of complex systems. The CPSs designed under this newly proposed paradigm will have vital social and economic implications, including the improvement of QoL and the reduction of lost productivity rates due to chronic diseases. HCPS could also prevent misuse, overuse, or underuse of medical care, thus improving healthcare efficiency. The educational and mentoring component incorporates multidisciplinary research across electrical engineering, neuroscience, bioengineering, system biology and computer science for creating the science of HCPSs that cross the boundaries of both academia and industry. Through its educational component, the project involved a diverse student body, expanding the project's outreach beyond the typical undergraduate and graduate demographics to high-school and middle-school students.


Last Modified: 09/02/2021
Modified by: Paul B Bogdan

Images (1 of )
  • A data-driven learning framework investigates the monitored cyber-physical processes from a microscopic perspective (e.g., magnitude & inter-event time increments), learns a causal non-Markovian dynamic model and provides the intelligent core of closed-loop CPSs for a wide spectrum of applications.
    Paul Bogdan
    Public Domain
    Paul B Bogdan
    Compact yet accurate mathematical modeling of complex dynamics and its application to the development of closed-loop cyber-physical systems.
  • Mathematical and algorithmic tools to uncover hidden patterns governing complex phenomena, learn compact perception dynamic models and estimate their parameters from multi-modal, scarce and noisy spatiotemporal data streams. This enables probabilistic reasoning for perception in autonomous CPS.
    Paul Bogdan and Gaurav Gupta
    Public Domain
    Paul B Bogdan
    Mathematical and algorithmic tools for compact perception in autonomous cyber-physical systems.
  • New mathematical and algorithmic tools for expressing cyber-physical system applications, extracting the optimal degree of parallelization from cyber-physical integrative task graphs, and determining the optimal amount of heterogeneous processors, memory & interconnect for CPS hardware realization.
    Paul Bogdan and Yao Xiao
    Public Domain
    Paul B Bogdan
    Novel design methodologies for cyber-physical systems: automated self-programming, self-optimization and synthetic from high level abstractions to hardware incarnations.
  • A CPS approach to inferring the network generators governing the neuronal interactions implementing cognitive processes. It differentiates the varying structures in the brain and chromosomal interactions. It can detect topologically associating domain regions in conformation maps of human genome.
    Paul Bogdan and Ruochen Yang
    Public Domain
    Paul B Bogdan
    A CPS approach to discovering the hidden network generating rules from partial, scarce, and noisy observations.
  • A CPS framework for understanding the mechanism by which neurons create or suppress connections to enable cognition demonstrates that neurons exhibit a self-optimizing network behavior with implications on designing the future generation of self-learning & self-optimizing AI architectures.
    Paul Bogdan and Chenzhong Yin
    Copyrighted
    Paul B Bogdan
    A cyber-physical system understanding of neuronal networks.
  • Traditional (A) vs. a CPS-based (B) in silico vaccine design. The CPS approach replaces the cumbersome and lengthy evaluations from traditional vaccine design with AI strategies to predict a set of vaccines within a second enabling fast evaluation and vaccine construction from small amount of data.
    Paul Bogdan and Zikun Yang
    Copyrighted
    Paul B Bogdan
    A cyber-physical systems approach to designing vaccines within seconds.
